content.title: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
content.summary: Gastroesophageal reflux disease is a chronic condition caused by retrograde flow of gastric contents into the esophagus, leading to symptoms (heartburn, regurgitation) and/or complications (esophagitis, stricture, Barrett's). It is one of the most common GI conditions, affecting 20% of the US population, and is managed primarily with lifestyle modifications and acid suppression therapy.
key_points: Classic symptoms: Heartburn and regurgitation (typical GERD)
Atypical: Chronic cough, laryngitis, asthma, chest pain
Erosive vs Non-erosive: Only 30-40% have visible esophagitis on endoscopy
First-line treatment: Lifestyle modifications + PPI for 8 weeks
Alarm symptoms: Dysphagia, weight loss, GI bleeding, anemia → endoscopy
Refractory GERD: Consider pH testing, impedance monitoring, fundoplication
content.statement: GERD is defined by troublesome symptoms or complications caused by reflux of gastric contents, diagnosed clinically and managed with lifestyle modifications and acid suppression, with endoscopy reserved for alarm symptoms or refractory cases.

explanation.intuition: Think of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) as a one-way valve that should only let food go down. In GERD, this valve is too relaxed (transient LES relaxations) or the pressure gradient favors reflux (hiatal hernia), allowing stomach acid to splash back up and burn the unprotected esophageal lining.
explanation.key_insight: Most GERD is diagnosed clinically based on typical symptoms responding to PPI trial - no testing needed. Endoscopy is NOT required for diagnosis but IS required for alarm symptoms, to evaluate complications, or for cancer surveillance in Barrett's.
explanation.technical_details: Transient LES relaxations (TLESRs) are the main mechanism in most GERD. Normal LES pressure is 10-35 mmHg. Hiatal hernia reduces LES competence. Acid pocket (unbuffered acid at gastric cardia) contributes to postprandial reflux. pH <4 in distal esophagus >4.2% of time is pathologic.

definitions_glossary.GERD: Condition where reflux of gastric contents causes troublesome symptoms or complications
definitions_glossary.heartburn: Burning retrosternal discomfort rising from stomach to throat; typical symptom
definitions_glossary.regurgitation: Perception of gastric contents in mouth/hypopharynx without effort
definitions_glossary.LES: Lower esophageal sphincter - muscular barrier preventing reflux
definitions_glossary.transient_LES_relaxation: Inappropriate LES relaxation not triggered by swallowing; main reflux mechanism
definitions_glossary.hiatal_hernia: Proximal stomach herniation through diaphragmatic hiatus; reduces LES function
definitions_glossary.erosive_esophagitis: Visible mucosal breaks on endoscopy; Los Angeles classification grades A-D
definitions_glossary.non_erosive_reflux_disease: GERD symptoms without visible esophageal injury (NERD)
definitions_glossary.peptic_stricture: Esophageal narrowing from chronic acid injury; causes dysphagia
definitions_glossary.Barrett_esophagus: Intestinal metaplasia of distal esophagus; premalignant condition
definitions_glossary.pH_monitoring: 24-48 hour recording of esophageal acid exposure for diagnosis
definitions_glossary.Bravo_capsule: Wireless pH monitoring device attached to esophageal mucosa

pathophysiology.mechanism: Disruption of anti-reflux barrier allowing gastric contents (acid, pepsin, bile) to contact esophageal mucosa, causing symptoms and tissue injury

progression.spectrum: NERD → Erosive esophagitis → Stricture → Barrett's → Adenocarcinoma
progression.note: Only 5-15% of GERD patients progress to Barrett's

clinical_diagnosis: Response to empiric PPI trial supports diagnosis
No further testing needed if typical presentation without alarm features

diagnostic_testing.upper_endoscopy: For alarm symptoms, screening Barrett's in high-risk, refractory symptoms
diagnostic_testing.ambulatory_pH_monitoring: Gold standard for documenting acid exposure; before surgery
diagnostic_testing.impedance_pH: Detects non-acid reflux; useful in PPI-refractory
diagnostic_testing.esophageal_manometry: Required before fundoplication to assess motility

lifestyle_modifications: Avoid eating within 3 hours of bedtime
Avoid trigger foods (coffee, alcohol, chocolate, fatty foods)

pharmacotherapy.first_line: PPI once daily 30-60 min before breakfast for 8 weeks
pharmacotherapy.maintenance: Lowest effective PPI dose for symptom control
pharmacotherapy.H2_blockers: Alternative for mild symptoms or step-down therapy

refractory_GERD: Consider additional H2 blocker at bedtime
Evaluate for non-acid reflux or functional heartburn

surgical_options.fundoplication: Laparoscopic Nissen (360°) or Toupet (270°); for refractory or large hiatal hernia
surgical_options.LINX_device: Magnetic sphincter augmentation; alternative to fundoplication
surgical_options.indications: Objective GERD, good symptom-reflux correlation, intolerant/refractory to PPI

definition.@value: A chronic condition characterized by retrograde flow of gastric contents into the esophagus, causing troublesome symptoms and/or mucosal complications

scopeNote.@value: Covers definition, diagnosis, and management of GERD and its complications

learning_objectives: Define GERD and distinguish typical from atypical symptoms
Identify alarm symptoms requiring endoscopic evaluation
Describe the role of pH monitoring and when to use it
Design initial management with lifestyle modifications and PPIs
clinical_pearls: Empiric PPI trial is diagnostic - if symptoms resolve, it's GERD
Only 30-40% of GERD patients have erosive esophagitis on EGD
PPIs should be taken 30-60 min BEFORE meals for optimal effect
Long-term PPI use is safe but periodically reassess need
Refractory symptoms: check compliance, timing, consider other diagnoses
common_misconceptions: All GERD patients need endoscopy - only for alarm symptoms or Barrett's screening
PPIs are dangerous long-term - benefits usually outweigh risks
Hiatal hernia causes GERD - it predisposes but is not sufficient
